To graft a substitutable interface onto a non-substitutable class:

1. Create the interface that you need the class to implement.
2. Create a wrapper class that implements the interface and accept an
object of the "bad class"'s type as a constructor parameter.
3. Have the new class delegate to the old class.

Voila. Substitutability out of thin air.

It's not nice, but it works and is likely as clean as it'll get.

So said  Matthew Cooke  on  2003-01-27 --------------------

>Sometimes it is not possible or atleast not trivial to make a mock. In

>particular with a final non-interfaced class. In this case it is not 
>possible to either write a mock based on the same interface or extend
the 
>class.
>
>There is a workaround to this, let's take java.net.URL as an example
of a 
>class with no useful interface and that is final.
>
>Simply don't use URL in your code. Always use your own interface say 
>'WebConnection'.
>
>RealWebConnection is a simple adapter on the URL with passthrough
methods 
>this is used everywhere a URL would be used.
>
>Now you can write tests for any classes that use webconnection as you
can 
>create a MockWebConnection.
>
>---
>There are other problems related to MockObject usage such as the
singleton 
>pattern. However there *are* workarounds to all problems and I have
seen
>no 
>situation where a test can not be written using MockObjects.
>
>Regards,
>Matt
>http://www.mockmaker.org
